Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Homelessne.Homelessness_with_annotation: Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia. This included Mount Nothofagus National Park and Nightcap National Park.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Injury.Injury_with_annotation: Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia. This included Mount Nothofagus National Park and Nightcap National Park.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Dry conditions in September 2019 contributed to several small to mid-range fires in north eastern New South Wales. By November of that year, continuing heat and lack of rain had desiccated the forests and agricultural land along the Great Dividing range in New South Wales and Queensland. Sydney received less than 2 millimetres (0.079 in) of rain in December 2019, with temperatures reaching 40°C (104°F). Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Displaceme.Displacement_with_annotation: In March 2021, above average rainfall led to serious and destructive flooding in the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment and on the Mid North Coast of New South Wales.

Location_with_Annotation.Victorian forests: An extremely dry six-month spell in Victorian forests contributed to the disastrous Black Friday bushfires of January 1939.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation: Drought: 'From 1996 to 2010, south-eastern Australia experienced prolonged dry conditions with rainfall persistently well below average, particularly during the cooler months from April to October.'|Wildfire: 'There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.'|Heatwave: 'The effects of the drought were exacerbated by Australia's (then) second hottest year on record in 2009, with record-breaking heatwaves in January, February and the second half of the year.'|Flood: 'In March 2021, above average rainfall led to serious and destructive flooding in the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment and on the Mid North Coast of New South Wales.'
